verses.text: Do not judge, so that you will not be judged.
verses.comment: This command warns believers against unjust or hypocritical judgment. It does not mean one should forsake discernment (see John 7:24), but cautions against condemning others self-righteously.

verses.text: For with the judgment you pass, you will be judged, and with the measure you use, it will be measured to you.
verses.comment: God applies the same standard to us that we use for others. The principle of reciprocity recalls God’s justice, connecting Old Testament concepts of mercy and judgment.

verses.text: Why do you look at the speck in your brother’s eye, but do not notice the log in your own eye?
verses.comment: Jesus uses a vivid image to highlight hypocrisy. Self-examination must precede correcting others, a principle for genuine spiritual growth.

verses.text: Or how can you say to your brother, ‘Let me take the speck out of your eye,’ when there is a log in your own eye?
verses.comment: Jesus condemns correcting others while remaining blind to one’s own faults. Spiritual leaders are especially called to integrity before guiding others.

verses.text: Hypocrite! First remove the log from your own eye, and then you will see clearly to take out the speck from your brother’s eye.
verses.comment: Self-purification is necessary before correcting others—a theme throughout Scripture (see James 1:22-25). This aligns with the call to holiness and accountability in the faith community.

verses.text: Do not give what is holy to dogs, nor cast your pearls before pigs, or they will trample them under foot and turn to attack you.
verses.comment: Sacred truth must be shared wisely. The imagery refers to discerning suitable contexts for holy things (as in liturgical or sacramental settings); not all are ready to receive deep truths.

verses.text: Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and the door will be opened to you.
verses.comment: Perseverance in prayer is encouraged. God is a generous Father (see verses 9-11). Seeking God earnestly includes persistent prayer, which also signifies trust in God’s providence.

verses.text: For everyone who asks receives; the one who seeks finds; and to the one who knocks, the door will be opened.
verses.comment: The universality of this promise shows God’s openness to sincere prayer, highlighting His fatherly care and the need for confidence in His wisdom.

verses.text: Or which one of you, if his son asks him for bread, will give him a stone?
verses.comment: Jesus uses a family image to illustrate God’s goodness. The contrast reflects the loving nature of God the Father as demonstrated in salvation history.

verses.text: Or if he asks for a fish, will give him a snake?
verses.comment: Here again, Jesus reassures us of God’s fatherly provision; He does not give what is harmful to His children.

verses.text: If you, then, who are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father in heaven give good things to those who ask Him!
verses.comment: The phrase 'who are evil' acknowledges human imperfection. God's generosity infinitely exceeds ours, reinforcing His unique role as the source of all grace.

verses.text: So whatever you want others to do to you, do likewise to them. For this is the Law and the Prophets.
verses.comment: Known as the Golden Rule, this summarizes the ethical teachings of the Old Testament (see Romans 13:10). Jesus delivers a unifying principle for moral living.

verses.text: Enter through the narrow gate. For wide is the gate and broad is the road that leads to destruction, and many enter through it.
verses.comment: Salvation requires choosing the difficult path of discipleship. The warning against the easy road reflects the need for obedience and perseverance, themes repeated throughout Jesus’ teaching.

verses.text: But small is the gate and narrow the way that leads to life, and few find it.
verses.comment: True discipleship is demanding. The rarity of those who find life calls for grace and cooperation with God’s will (see Philippians 2:12-13).

verses.text: Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s clothing, but inwardly are ravenous wolves.
verses.comment: Authenticity in teaching is essential. The flock must guard against deceptive leaders, which underscores the importance of apostolic succession and tradition in discerning truth.

verses.text: You will recognize them by their fruits. Do people gather grapes from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
verses.comment: Genuine faith results in visible good works. Spiritual discernment is exercised by inspecting the fruits of teaching and practice.

verses.text: So, every good tree produces good fruit, and a rotten tree produces bad fruit.
verses.comment: Ethical life and authentic doctrine go hand in hand. The imagery ties back to prophetic warnings of Israel’s unfaithfulness (Isa. 5:1-7).

verses.text: A good tree cannot produce bad fruit, nor can a rotten tree produce good fruit.
verses.comment: This absolute statement refers to the necessity for inward spiritual renewal. Only by God’s grace do believers bring forth holy works.

verses.text: Every tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.
verses.comment: There are consequences for failing to live according to God’s will. This future judgment connects to images of purification and the final destiny of souls.

verses.text: So then, by their fruits you will recognize them.
verses.comment: A practical means for judging teaching and leaders: observe outcomes over time.

verses.text: Not everyone who says to me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ will enter the kingdom of heaven, but only the one who does the will of my Father in heaven.
verses.comment: Faith must be lived out through obedience. Jesus anticipates being approached as Lord on the last day, reflecting His unique role in salvation and judgment. Here is a strong christological claim: Jesus stands as final judge.

verses.text: Many will say to me on that day, ‘Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name and cast out demons in your name, and do many mighty works in your name?’
verses.comment: Spiritual gifts or outward works alone are not enough without true discipleship. Jesus' claim about 'that day' refers to the final judgment—He identifies Himself as judge over all humanity, underlining His divinity.

verses.text: Then I will declare to them, ‘I never knew you; depart from me, you who work lawlessness!’
verses.comment: Knowledge of Jesus is not just verbal confession but a relationship deepened by obedience. 'Lawlessness' recalls the importance of both faith and the works produced by genuine faith.

verses.text: Everyone who hears these words of mine and does them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock.
verses.comment: Authentic discipleship means hearing and practicing Jesus’ teaching. Christ is the foundation, echoing Old Testament references where God alone is the Rock (see Deut. 32:4; 1 Cor. 10:4).

verses.text: The rain came down, the floods rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house—but it did not fall, because it had its foundation on the rock.
verses.comment: Testing comes to all. A life built on Jesus and His teachings remains secure. Note the symbolic reference to sacraments as means of 'building on the rock.'

verses.text: But everyone who hears these words of mine and does not do them is like a foolish man who built his house on sand.
verses.comment: Obedience is necessary for spiritual stability. Hearing alone is not adequate; the faith must be visible in action (see James 2:17-26).

verses.text: The rain came down, the floods rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house, and it fell—and great was its fall.
verses.comment: Faith without commitment to Jesus and His commands results in destruction. The warning recalls Old Testament judgment imagery (Ezek. 13:10-16).

verses.text: And when Jesus finished these words, the crowds were amazed at His teaching.
verses.comment: Jesus teaches with an authority greater than the scribes. His words cause amazement, showing His role as the ultimate teacher, and the new Moses foretold in Deut. 18:15.

verses.text: For He was teaching them as one who had authority, and not as their scribes.
verses.comment: Unlike the scribes, Jesus speaks with divine authority, fulfilling Old Testament expectations of a prophet like Moses—yet greater, for He is the Word made flesh.
